assessmentEvidence.extentions:
Students will show their learning by…

Research Project - How do site conditions affect oyster growth?

  • Look at your data from the Site Conditions protocol.
  • Choose a Site Conditions data point that you think may be having an impact (positive or negative) on your Oyster Restoration Station.
  • Find another ORS site that has entries for the same data point and compare to your ORS site.
  • Find another data point (possibly from another protocol) that may be tied to the site condition (i.e. lots of rainfall and salinity; lots of outfall pipes and nutrients).
  • Draw a conclusion as to how the restoration stations are being impacted and make a suggestion for improvement.
  • Visually represent your data and your suggestions for improvement.
  • This project is best suited for Oyster Restoration Stations located in proximity to CSO, or other effluent outfall pipes.

evidence.scienceAndEngineering:
Engaging in Argument from Evidence

Engaging in argument from evidence in 6–8 builds on K–5 experiences and progresses to constructing a convincing argument that supports or refutes claims for either explanations or solutions about the natural and designed world(s).

  • Construct an oral and written argument supported by empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support or refute an explanation or a model for a phenomenon or a solution to a problem.

Connections to Nature of Science

Scientific Knowledge is Based on Empirical Evidence
  • Science disciplines share common rules of obtaining and evaluating empirical evidence.
evidence.disciplinaryCoreIdeas:
LS2.C: Ecosystem Dynamics, Functioning, and Resilience
  • Ecosystems are dynamic in nature; their characteristics can vary over time. Disruptions to any physical or biological component of an ecosystem can lead to shifts in all its populations.
evidence.crossCuttingConcepts:
Cross-Cutting Concepts
Stability and Change
  • Small changes in one part of a system might cause large changes in another part.

essentialQuestions: What are the interactions between water, land and air within the NY Harbor Estuary System in New York Harbor? How do the different components affect each other?

enduringUnderstandings.fieldWork: New York Harbor’s ecology is urban. In New York, city, air, and land are all interconnected. Changes in one can affect the entire system. Human actions add additional layers of impact on the system and change the quality of the interactions.

assessmentEvidence.extentions:
Research Project - Design your own oyster reef in New York Harbor

  • Using your own data in addition data from other parts of the harbor, choose what you believe to be the “best” location to install an experimental reef
  • Visually represent your data and data from another part of the harbor to support your location choice
  • Use your knowledge of oyster anatomy, and the oysters ability to filters and build reefs to inform your choice of location
  • Using not only the oyster growth data, but also the water quality, organism, and water/land conditions data, design the foundation of the experimental reef.  What will it look like and why?
  • How would you know your design is working? What data would you measure? What changes are you looking for? (Consider oysters and other organisms as well) 
  • Create a visual representation of your final project showing supporting data and final design

Extensions:
  • use a collaborative process (design charrette)
  • research and refer to previous restoration projects to explain why yours would work
  • create a budget for the experimental reef
  • design competition - teams present their ideas for evaluation/critique

evidence.scienceAndEngineering:
Engaging in Argument from Evidence
  • Evaluate competing design solutions based on jointly developed and agreed-upon design criteria.
evidence.disciplinaryCoreIdeas:
LS2.C: Ecosystem Dynamics, Functioning, and Resilience
  • Biodiversity describes the variety of species found in Earth’s terrestrial and oceanic ecosystems. The completeness or integrity of an ecosystem’s biodiversity is often used as a measure of its health.

Stability and Change
  • Small changes in one part of a system might cause large changes in another part.

essentialQuestions: Why do oysters matter and how do we restore them?

enduringUnderstandings.fieldWork: Oysters were once a keystone species in the New York Harbor estuary system. Oysters are an important species to restore because they create habitat for other animals and they filter the water.

assessmentEvidence.extentions:
Research Project: Who lives in my Oyster Restoration Station?

  • Choose an organism that you find on YOUR oyster restoration station.
  • Design food web around chosen organism.  
  • Must include oysters.
  • Must include all levels of the trophic pyramid (i.e. plankton, decomposers).
  • Must research what these organisms eat and accurately display on food web.
  • Find all other ORS locations that have this organism.  Which ORS has the greatest number and which has the least of this organism?  Graph organism distribution data.  (Make a hypothesis as to why if you feel you have enough data).
  • Write about the importance of biodiversity and how your individual organism contributes to biodiversity.

Extensions:
  • Research parameters that your organism can live in (water quality for each individual organism)

evidence.scienceAndEngineering:
Developing and Using Models
  • Develop a model to describe phenomena
evidence.disciplinaryCoreIdeas:
LS2.B: Cycle of Matter and Energy Transfer in Ecosystems
  • Food webs are models that demonstrate how matter and energy is transferred between producers, consumers, and decomposers as the three groups interact within an ecosystem. Transfers of matter into and out of the physical environment occur at every level. Decomposers recycle nutrients from dead plant or animal matter back to the soil in terrestrial environments or to the water in aquatic
evidence.crossCuttingConcepts:
Energy and Matter
  • The transfer of energy can be tracked as energy flows through a natural system.

essentialQuestions: What mobile organisms are found in the Oyster Restoration Station and how do they relate to each other and their environment?

enduringUnderstandings.fieldWork: NY Harbor estuary system is currently home to many marine species, but it would benefit from greater biodiversity.  Oyster and other organisms interact and affect each other.

assessmentEvidence.extentions:
Research Project: Who lives in my Oyster Restoration Station?
  • Choose an organism that you find on YOUR oyster restoration station.
  • Design food web around chosen organism.  
  • Must include oysters.
  • Must include all levels of the trophic pyramid (i.e. plankton, decomposers).
  • Must research what these organisms eat and accurately display on food web.
  • Find all other ORS locations that have this organism.  Which ORS has the greatest number and which has the least of this organism?  Graph organism distribution data.  (Make a hypothesis as to why if you feel you have enough data).
  • Write about the importance of biodiversity and how your individual organism contributes to biodiversity.

Extensions:
  • Research parameters that your organism can live in (water quality for each individual organism)

evidence.scienceAndEngineering:
Developing and Using Models
  • Develop a model to describe phenomena.
evidence.disciplinaryCoreIdeas:
LS2.B: Cycle of Matter and Energy Transfer in Ecosystems
  • Food webs are models that demonstrate how matter and energy is transferred between producers, consumers, and decomposers as the three groups interact within an ecosystem. Transfers of matter into and out of the physical environment occur at every level. Decomposers recycle nutrients from dead plant or animal matter back to the soil in terrestrial environments or to the water in aquatic environments. The atoms that make up the organisms in an ecosystem are cycled repeatedly between the living and nonliving parts of the ecosystem.
evidence.crossCuttingConcepts:
Energy and Matter
  • The transfer of energy can be tracked as energy flows through a natural system.

essentialQuestions: What sessile organisms are found in the Oyster Restoration Station?

enduringUnderstandings.fieldWork: NY Harbor has a variety of life under the surface of the water. Much of what covers underwater surfaces in NY Harbor is living organisms.

assessmentEvidence.extentions:
Research Project - Improving Wastewater Treatment

  • Examine the combined sewer overflow and wastewater treatment process in New York City.
  • Assess and/or design feasible solutions to improving the wastewater treatment process.
  • Choose a water quality parameters that is impacted by the wastewater treatment process.
  • Compare your data with data from other ORS location(s) around the harbor (focus on locations that are in proximity to CSO or effluent outfalls).
  • Create a visual representation of the data comparison.
  • Create a visual representation of your final project showing supporting data and final hypothesis for minimizing impact of wastewater treatment and combined sewer overflows.

evidence.scienceAndEngineering:
Constructing Explanations and Designing Solutions
Constructing explanations and designing solutions in 6–8 builds on K–5 experiences and progresses to include constructing explanations and designing solutions supported by multiple sources of evidence consistent with scientific ideas, principles, and theories.
  • Apply scientific principles to design an object, tool, process or system.
evidence.disciplinaryCoreIdeas:
ESS3.C: Human Impacts on Earth Systems
  • Human activities have significantly altered the biosphere, sometimes damaging or destroying natural habitats and causing the extinction of other species. But changes to Earth’s environments can have different impacts (negative and positive) for different living things.
  • Typically as human populations and per-capita consumption of natural resources increase, so do the negative impacts on Earth unless the activities and technologies involved are engineered otherwise.
evidence.crossCuttingConcepts:
Cause and Effect
  • Relationships can be classified as causal or correlational, and correlation does not necessarily imply causation.

Connections to Engineering, Technology, and Applications of Science
 
Influence of Science, Engineering, and Technology on Society and the Natural World
  • The uses of technologies and any limitations on their use are driven by individual or societal needs, desires, and values; by the findings of scientific research; and by differences in such factors as climate, natural resources, and economic conditions. Thus technology use varies from region to region and over time.

lessons.science:
• Water quality parameters
  • What is _____?
  • In what unit do we measure it?
  • What instrument allows us to measure it?
  • What causes it to increase or decrease?
  • What does it tell us about the water quality?
  • What affect does it have on oysters?
  • Algae blooms
  • Anoxia/hypoxia
  • What pollutants can we test for?
  • What does water quality tell us about NY Harbor?
  • Water Quality parameters for most important or most commonly seen organisms (i.e. oyster, blue crab, sea squirt, etc.)

essentialQuestions: What are the characteristics of water and why are they important?

enduringUnderstandings.fieldWork: Water has many characteristics and components, each of which can be measured The quality of the water affects what live in it.
